utterances: No, just the smart ones.
Now, Tiger, he's talked a lot about how it was his intense practice sessions that have helped him not miss a beat out here.
And I think we're also seeing his supreme talent as a golfer, probably the most talented ever - the ability to come back and lock on immediately.
We're also seeing his supreme arrogance in a good and a bad way, Scott.
Good in that he has the confidence and belief in himself to do this.
Bad in that he continues to say he had to practice extra hard because he didnt have the luxury of playing tournaments during his time away from golf, as if he were being denied an opportunity.
As reporter here said, Tiger, buddy, that was your choice to remove yourself from the scene.
Your choice to get yourself into the little mess you did.
No one was denying you.
Hmm.
I want to talk about these two British guys, Ian Poulter and Lee Westwood, while we have the chance.
They're really has been a whole, forgive the expression, renaissance of the Brits doing very well in the international tournaments.
Well, they have.
You know, and here's what Lee Westwood would say to you though, Scott.
In that wonderful British way of calling someone a schmuck, while sipping a cup of tea and smiling...
(Soundbite of laughter)
...I'm not saying Im calling you that, Scott.
But Westwood responded to a reporter who said is this verification of the British renaissance in golf.
He said if you think thats so, you simply haven't checked the recent roll of ranking.
There are three Brits in the top 10, Westwood is number four.
Poulter is number seven.
They're darn good and they have been trending upward recently, as we say.
Poulter is very flamboyant in both his talk and his clothing.
He loves more than a hint of color on the golf course.
Yesterday, he was resplendent in pin pants, yellow shirt, white shoes with a just a little pink stitching, and...
My exact outfit today.
(Soundbite of laughter)
And his love of natty attire prompted the following question from a reporter.
You like to make bold fashion statements.
What color combination goes well with a green jacket?
What?
What color combination goes well with a green jacket?
Absolutely anything.
(Soundbite of laughter)
The green jacket, of course, Scott.
The green sport coat goes to the winner of the Masters.
Yeah.
Tom, has nobody shouted anything ugly or even just a little bit curious at Tiger Woods, as he stalks the course?
No.
No. There have been no reports of heckling.
Security has been very tight.
I've recognized the same security guards walking along in the gallery with Tiger during his rounds.
Reportedly, security guards have had mug shots of Tiger's mistresses, so they are ready to pounce - so to speak - if they see someone.
Particularly...
Forgive me.
That must be quite a collection.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Exactly.
You know, like unrolling one of those scrolls, yeah.
No, particularly in the opening practice rounds when more people were on the course, but no. And, you know, Scott, the whole elephant in the room has become a mouse here.
There's hardly a mention of the scandal.
Just this plan by Team Tiger, you know, we're seeing why he returned to Augusta.
Very polite, knowledgeable golf fans here.
The patrons, as they're called, are here to see golf and not fuss with all that scandal stuff.
Of course, what happens after this bubble of protection at the Masters is anyone's guess.
And, you know, theyve given us a few more seconds on the clock, Tom.
So there are a lot of players from around the world who are doing very well in this early round, aren't there?
Well, there are.
You know, I mentioned the people right behind the leaders, four Americans: Woods, and Mickelson, and Anthony Kim, and Ricky Barnes.
Should also mention the South Koreans, Y.E.
Yang and K.J.
Choi, yes, they're representative.
Lots of people from other countries, it certainly is a United Nations of golf, of course, with the English on top right now.
Yeah.
Well, may...
(Soundbite of laughter)
...Britannia rules the greens, at least until later this afternoon.
NPR's Tom Goldman from the Masters in Augusta, Georgia, thanks so much.
You're welcome.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
Let's begin this next segment by stipulating that smoking is bad for you.
Worse than that - smoking kills.
On the movie screen, it can very romantic.
Think Bette Davis in ""Now, Voyager"".
It can be atmospheric.
Imagine the darkening gloom inside Rick's Cafe American as the war clouds gather in ""Casablanca"".
A Chesterfield in the corner of a private detective's mouth tells us one thing.
A smoke ring blown by a vixen, quite another.
Now the Motion Picture Association of America will rate new movie releases on how they depict smoking, as well as on sex and violence.
So how important is smoking to the movies, and will efforts to banish butts reduce consumption or make them even more attractive?
Our number is 800-989-8255.
That's 800-989-TALK.
Email us: talk@npr.org.
There's also a conversation at our blog, npr.org/blogofthenation.
Joining us to talk about Hollywood's relationship with the cigarette is Richard Klein, professor of French at Cornell University, author of ""Cigarettes are Sublime"".
He joins us from our studios in New York City.
Nice to you on the program today.
Hi, Neal.
And Casablanca would've gotten an R rating, I suspect, under the new rules of the Motion Picture Association of America.
Hasn't smoking always been acceptable?
Not even acceptable, but sort of lauded in Hollywood?
Okay.
Yes.

I just wanted to - the question was already asked, like, how is it going to affect the characters if they were to smoke or, you know, the characters that smoke - sometimes, the smoking of a character will define that character.
(As Grover) Thank you.
We reached out to Celltex to see if we could talk to co-founder Dr. Stanley Jones, or someone else at the company, about the work that they do.
They put us in touch with their lawyer, Andrea Ferrenz.
She represents Celltex before the FDA.
Ferrenz says Celltex is not selling a cure to sick people.
She says the company only provides treatment when independent doctors request the company's services for their patients.
We actually don't employ physicians that provide treatments.
We're really a laboratory, a laboratory service provider.
We're providing a therapeutic product.
So Dr. Jones never treated patients?
You're talking about Stan Jones?
Yeah.
He is an independent physician.
He does not have a clinic here at Celltex.
He is on our board of directors, but he does not operate out of Celltex.
He has his own, spinal surgery practice.
Does Dr. Jones send his patients to Celltex?
He has had patients that come to Celltex that he ordered products for, but we have other physicians as well, that order products through Celltex.
Ferrenz says this is not a conflict.
Dr. Jones is only one of many doctors who want their patients to undergo adult stem cell replacement.
And she says Dr. Jones is a patient himself.
He has said that stem cell replacement cured him of arthritis.
Ferrenz says the move to Mexico is about expanding their growing business.
We're bringing this technology to Mexico.
It would be through physicians in Mexico.
You know, a lot of people might hear that and think of, you know, a guy behind a door on a street in Mexico, you know, who says he's a doctor.
And if you want to get the Celltex process, you just knock on his door, and he'll send you over to Celltex.
I mean, there's something that sounds like there's less regulation, perhaps, in that process than there might have been in the United States.
It's unfortunate that that might be the impression people have.
We have met with very highly credible physicians - and will be working with very highly credible physicians and excellent hospitals - that are in Mexico.
And COFEPRIS, Mexico's equivalent of the FDA, is as concerned with safety for the people in its country as the U.S.
FDA.
